A lightweight Context Guided convolutional neural network architecture is proposed for semantic segmentation of tropical cyclones and atmospheric rivers in climate data. The primary focus is on tropical cyclones, the most destructive weather events, for which current models show limited performance. We investigate feature engineering, data augmentation, learning rate modifications, alternative loss functions, and architectural changes. Unlike previous approaches that optimize for intersection over union, we aim to improve recall to penalize under-counting and prioritize the identification of tropical cyclones. We report success through the use of weighted loss functions to counter class imbalance for these rare events.

Climate action failure and extreme weather are two of the most severe global risks today. Tropical cyclones, the most destructive extreme weather events, have a rising and disproportionate impact on low- and medium-income countries. Research into their effects focuses mostly on high-income countries. Studies of extreme weather and climate change rely on heuristics or expert judgment to label data, leading to an inequitable global scientific focus and discrepancies in predicted frequency, intensity, and attribution estimates. Improving automated detection of extreme weather events is crucial for fair attribution of climate loss and damages and for developing early warning and detection systems that will be critical for equitable adaptation to climate change.

Since 2020, deep learning has shown great promise for semantic segmentation of weather patterns in climate simulation data. However, initial approaches have relied on complex architectures and hard-to-train models with very large numbers of parameters. A key area of research is the application of lightweight neural networks to semantic segmentation of tropical cyclones and atmospheric rivers. We explore the application of the lightweight Context Guided convolutional neural network (CGNet) architecture to semantic segmentation of tropical cyclones in climate data. The input to our model is hand-labeled climate simulation data with channels containing key atmospheric variables such as wind speed, moisture content, and atmospheric pressure for different time steps, latitudes, and longitudes. The output is a segmentation mask where each pixel takes a value corresponding to the background, TC, or AR classes.

Specific challenges include the small dataset size, inherent class imbalance of infrequent extreme events, unavoidable bias due to subjective human labeling, and limited capacity of the lightweight network. We report experiments with different hyperparameters (loss function, learning rate), architecture (up-sampling), data augmentation, and feature engineering. We find that weighted loss functions aimed at compensating class imbalance provide the most significant improvement on recall of extreme weather events.

Initial inspiration for this work came from Prabhat et al. (2021), which trained a DeepLabV3+ convolutional neural network on the ClimateNet expert-label dataset. This model achieved an intersection over union (IoU) score of 0.24 for TCs and was the first to demonstrate that deep learning models trained on hand-labeled climate data could effectively perform semantic segmentation of extreme weather patterns. However, the DeepLabV3+ architecture is complex, heavy, and costly in terms of memory, training time, and associated carbon footprint.

In a related work, Kapp-Schwoerer et al. (2020b) attempted to perform the same segmentation task on the ClimateNet dataset with the much lighter-weight Context Guided neural architecture. They improved on Prabhat et al. (2021) with a IoU score of 0.34 and a recall of 0.57 for TCs, our primary class of interest. This model and its associated metrics form our performance baseline. For a detailed presentation of Context Guided convolutional neural networks, we refer the reader to the original paper that introduced the CGNet architecture. To solve the class imbalance problem, we experimented with various loss functions reviewed in Jadon (2020).
